initial_dialogue.title: Initial Assessment
initial_dialogue.message: Everyone’s experience with Parkinson’s is different. It can affect your body, your mood, your energy — and your everyday life. Let’s start with a few simple statements to explore what matters most to you right now. Choose the ones you’d like to focus on.

options.text: I want to pay attention to my physical symptoms or understand body changes.
I want to stay active — physically, socially, or through hobbies.
I've noticed changes in my mood, memory, or focus — I'd like to pay more attention to that.
I want to understand my medication and manage my treatment.
I'd like guidance to manage daily living activities more easily and improve my well-being.

final_dialogue.title: Care Priorities Summary
final_dialogue.finalmessage_followedbyBulletList: Thanks for sharing what matters most to you. Here's a quick summary of the care priorities you've selected:
final_dialogue.finalmessage_question: Would you like to move on and set your goals now, or would you prefer to chat with me again to add other care priorities?

options.text: Set my goals now
Restart the conversation with CAFY

steps.message: You’ve chosen to focus on your physical symptoms and body changes. Let’s take a closer look at what’s been affecting you most. Which of these areas would you like to pay more attention to right now?
steps.message_after_selection: Thanks — let’s take a closer look at [selected_areas_name], and set a goal to help you feel more comfortable and supported day by day.

options.name: Moving & Walking
options.text: Moving & Walking — Trouble walking, freezing, or keeping your balance.

options.name: Body Reactions & Pain
options.text: Body Reactions & Pain — Aches, sharp pain, dizziness, sweating, or skin changes.

options.name: Saliva Control & Swallowing
options.text: Saliva control — Extra saliva or slow swallowing.

options.name: Bowel & Bladder
options.text: Bowel & Bladder Dysfunction — Constipation, bloating, or needing to urinate often.

options.name: Sleep & Fatigue
options.text: Sleep Disorders & Fatigue — Trouble falling asleep, waking at night, or feeling exhausted.

options.name: Sensory & Voice Changes
options.text: Sensory & Voice Changes — Blurry vision, reduced smell/taste, tingling, or weak voice.

steps.message: Many people with Parkinson's notice changes in how they walk or move — like slowness, freezing, or trouble keeping their balance. To better support your mobility, I'd like to ask a few simple questions.

options.name: Tremor
options.text: Do you experience any shaking or tremors?

options.name: Bradykinesia-slow movement
options.text: Are your movements slower than they used to be?

options.name: Balance
options.text: Do you sometimes feel unsteady or afraid of falling?

options.name: Gait Freezing
options.text: Have you had moments where your feet feel "stuck" or frozen when you try to start walking?

steps.message: People with Parkinson's can feel different kinds of discomfort — sometimes it's pain, sometimes it's other changes that affect your body and sensations. Which of these symptoms has been the most bothersome for you lately?

options.name: Pain
options.text: Pain — like muscle or joint aches, cramping, or unexplained pain.

options.name: Light-headedness (Dizziness)
options.text: Light-headedness or dizziness — especially when standing up.

options.name: Unusual Sweating
options.text: Unusual sweating — sweating too much or too little.

options.name: Skin Changes
options.text: Skin changes — dryness, itchiness, or irritation.

steps.message: Some people with Parkinson's notice more saliva in their mouth or trouble swallowing—especially at night or during meals. Have you noticed any of the following?

options.name: Drooling
options.text: Do you feel like you have too much saliva in your mouth?

options.name: Swallowing
options.text: Do you ever find it difficult to chew or swallow food or drinks?

steps.message: Parkinson's can slow down how your gut and bladder work. This might lead to constipation or more frequent trips to the bathroom, especially at night. These changes can affect your comfort and your sleep. Can you tell me which of these has been more of a problem for you lately?

options.name: Constipation
options.text: Constipation - Do you often feel bloated or have trouble passing stool?

options.name: Urinary issues
options.text: Urinary issues — Do you need to pee often, especially at night, or feel like your bladder doesn't empty fully?

steps.message: Parkinson’s can affect both your sleep and your energy during the day. You might find it harder to fall or stay asleep, feel very tired even after resting, or notice strange sensations in your legs at night. Which of these feels most important to you right now?

options.name: Insomnia
options.text: Insomnia — Do you often wake up at night or struggle to fall asleep?

options.name: Daytime sleepiness
options.text: Daytime sleepiness — Do you feel drowsy during the day or fall asleep without meaning to?

options.name: Fatigue
options.text: Fatigue — Do you feel deeply tired or worn out, even after resting?

options.name: Restless legs
options.text: Restless legs — Do you feel a need to move your legs at night, or get uncomfortable sensations when lying down?

steps.message: I've got a few quick questions to help you figure out which sensory change matters most right now:

options.name: Vision problems
options.text: Do you find your vision blurry, see double, or notice your eyes feel dry when you read?

options.name: Smell loss
options.text: Have scents you used to enjoy becoming fainter or disappeared?

options.name: Taste loss
options.text: Do foods taste dull or lack their usual flavor?

options.name: Abnormal sensations
options.text: Are you experiencing odd sensations—like tingling, burning, or numb spots in your body?

options.name: Speech problems
options.text: Does your voice feel weak or faint when you speak, making it hard for others to hear you?

steps.message: Staying active is a powerful way to care for yourself — whether that means moving, connecting with others, or doing what brings you joy. Where would you like to focus attention right now?
steps.message_after_selection: Thanks — let’s take a closer look at [selected_areas_name], and set a goal to help you feel more comfortable and supported day by day.

options.name: Staying Active
options.text: Staying active — like doing exercises, walking, stretching, or doing hobbies that keep your body and mind engaged.

options.name: Social Relationships
options.text: Taking care of your social life & relationships – maintaining bonds, sharing moments with others, and staying socially and emotionally engaged.

steps.message: Staying active is one of your best tools against Parkinson's. Which sounds most motivating right now?

options.name: Physical activity
options.text: Would you like to be more active by walking, stretching, or doing other kinds of exercise?

options.name: Hobbies
options.text: Would you like to spend more time on a hobby or activity you enjoy?

steps.message: Whether it’s spending time with loved ones, planning a small outing, or staying emotionally close to someone who matters — taking care of your relationships is part of taking care of yourself. Here are some common areas where people need support. Just let me know what feels most relevant for you right now.

options.name: Living connected
options.text: Is staying socially connected important to you right now?

options.name: Leisure
options.text: Would you like help planning social activities, vacations or going out more often?

options.name: Caregiver Respite
options.text: Are you looking for ways to support your caregivers or make family life feel more balanced?

options.name: Intimacy
options.text: Would you like help understanding how Parkinson's may affect your intimacy or emotional closeness?

steps.message: People with Parkinson could notice some changes in their mood, memory, or perception. Being aware of these changes is a way to take care of yourself. Let’s take a moment to better understand what you’ve been going through. Which of these areas would you like to focus on first?
steps.message_after_selection: Thanks — let’s take a closer look at [selected_areas_name], and set a goal to help you feel more comfortable and supported day by day.

options.name: Emotional & Behavioral Changes
options.text: Emotional & Behavioral Changes - Feeling anxious, low, angry, or unmotivated.

options.name: Memory & Focus
options.text: Memory & Focus - Having trouble remembering or concentrating.

options.name: Perceptions
options.text: Seeing or hearing things — Perceiving things that aren't there, or feeling confused by surroundings.

steps.message: Changes in how you feel are common with Parkinson's, and you're not alone. Let's take a closer look at what's been affecting you most lately. Which of these has felt most present or difficult for you recently?

options.name: Anxiety & Panick Attack
options.text: Anxiety & Panick Attack  - Have you recently felt sudden fear or anxiety that caused physical reactions, like a racing heart or shortness of breath?

options.name: Impulsive behavior
options.text: Impulsive behavior - Have you noticed urges that feel hard to control—like overspending, overeating?

options.name: Emotional changes (Depression)
options.text: Emotional changes (Depression) - Have you been feeling down or less motivated than usual lately?

steps.message: You might notice that daily tasks and new information are difficult to remember. These changes can creep in slowly, so it helps to name them. Have you noticed any of these?

options.name: Forgetfulness
options.text: Have you been forgetting things more often, like names, appointments, or steps in a task you usually do with ease?

options.name: Mental Overload
options.text: Do you feel overwhelmed or find it hard to focus when there's a lot going on, or when decisions need to be made?

options.name: Brain Fog
options.text: Have you noticed it takes more time to understand or respond to things, or that judging distances or space feels harder?

steps.message: Sometimes, Parkinson's can cause us to not be aware of things we see or hear. Do you experience any of the following:

options.name: Hallucinations
options.text: Seeing things or hearing voices or sounds that others don't.

options.name: False beliefs
options.text: Feeling confused, suspicious, or firmly convinced of things that later don't seem to make sense.

options.name: Perceptual Distortion
options.text: Feeling confused by objects or surroundings, and it takes a moment to figure out what's real.

steps.message: Managing Parkinson's every day starts with your medication routine. When you take your medication at the right time and dose, you give yourself the best chance to reduce "off" periods and feel more in control throughout your day. But managing symptoms it's also about understanding how your body reacts. Would you like to:
steps.message_after_selection: Thanks — let’s take a closer look at [selected_areas_name], and set a goal to help you feel more comfortable and supported day by day.

options.name: Medication Adherence
options.text: Build a strong medication routine

options.name: Side Effects Awareness
options.text: Record side effects or something unusual you've noticed

steps.message: Managing your home life, meals, and daily routines can take effort — but small changes can make a big difference. Let's take a closer look at what might help you most right now. Where would you like to focus your attention?
steps.message_after_selection: Thanks — let’s take a closer look at [selected_areas_name], and set a goal to help you feel more comfortable and supported day by day.

options.name: Weight & Nutrition
options.text: Would support with meals or diet be helpful to you right now?

options.name: Daily Tasks & Reorganizing Space
options.text: Would you like help making daily tasks easier or finding simple ways to feel safer and more independent at home?

steps.message: What you eat — and how your body responds — can really affect how you feel day to day. Let's see where you'd like support.

options.name: Weight
options.text: Do you want to better manage weight loss or gain linked to Parkinson's?

options.name: Nutrition
options.text: Would you like to improve digestion, energy, or balanced meals?

steps.message: Everyday activities — like getting dressed, cooking, or moving safely around your home — can take extra effort with Parkinson's. Let's see where you need support.

options.name: Empowering Daily Life
options.text: Would you like help making daily routines easier and more manageable?

options.name: Enhancing Physical Safety
options.text: Would you feel more secure if you had support for balance, falls, or home safety?
